2.title: Logical Data Models
2.content: Logical Data Models are defined in FHIR as an abstract representation of the data, independent from any technology implementation. Logical Data Models and terminology bindings . Logical Data Models can include terminology bindings. This is the case when the values in the valueset have a “official” meaning - like marital status, or country codes, for example. In such cases, the codes are not only a FHIR technical consideration, but they are supposed to be the same across implementations, across technologies and standards. This means that when defining the logical models, these valuesets should also be defined. Profiling from Logical Models . The following guidelines apply when creating profiles from a logical model . | All elements in the logical model shall be in the profile, as a Must Support | The data type and cardinality of the all elements in the logical model shall be reflected on the profile | Any terminology bindings that are in the logical model shall also be present in the profile - the valuesets used in the logical model can also be used in the profile | .

3.title: Data Specifications
3.content: Specifying the data to be exchanged is a key part of interoperability specifications. The process to specify data is: . | Define a logical data model | Derive the profiles, using extensions as needed | Define and implement terminologies - valuesets and codesystems | .

4.title: Deployment
4.content: Belgium FHIR specifications are deployment ready .

5.title: Deployment tracking
5.content: Tracking implementations can be done by . | Define a list of “officially-defined” capabilities | For each system, document the capabilities that the system supports . | Possibly as a result of an accreditation or testing process | . | . For this, we can keep a catalog of CapabilityStatements: . | The CapabilityStatement definitions, that can be used in the Belgian architecture | The CapabilityStatement instances of those definitions, representing a system’s implementation of a capability. | . To document this, we have an ImplementationGuide that describes how CapabilitySatement can be used for this: https://github.com/hl7-be/fhir-capability-map. With this structure, it becomes relatively easy to tag the instance with geographical coordinates, for example. This is demonstrated here: https://hl7-be.github.io/fhir-capability-map/map/map.html.

7.title: Deployment tracking
7.content: Tracking of the development and adoption of FHIR specifications is achieved at the level of transactions.

8.title: List of HL7 Belgium FHIR working groups

10.title: HL7 Belgium process documentation
10.content: This publication contains the processes used by HL7 Belgium in the definition and publication of HL7 FHIR standards in Belgium. It contains the key artifacts, the roles, and the general way of working within the strict scope of HL7 Belgium working groups. This interfaces with other stakeholders that play a role in creating and publishing standards - namely eHealth, the Program Board B, the different federal working groups - Architecture and Structuring Elements, as well as the broad community. While those adjacent processes are identified here, this documentation does not represent those other processes - this documentation site maintains only the HL7 processes and technologies; all other processes are the responsibility of the respective owners, and are just identified here for a clear understanding of the collaboration.

12.title: Bindings
12.content: When a valueset binding is relevant functionally - for example the use of ISO country codes is relevant functionally so that every implementation uses them..

13.title: Data types
13.content: Logical vs physical data types . Using data types . When a data type is relevant functionally .

15.title: Publication
15.content: The publication process starts with a project initiation phase, which starts with a proposal that describes the content, and is evaluated by the working parties. The project proposal can be presented by any company or organization member of HL7 Belgium, and . The project proposal template is in… The project proposals are listed in … and deposited in … .

17.title: Server deployment
17.content: Server . | Ensure that your IG has no errors in the qa.html page | make sure your package id is correct i.e. no dots or dashes | use the BE template for generating the application.yaml file | run the command line docker run -p 8080:8080 -e hapi.fhir.default_encoding=json -e "--spring.config.location=https://hl7belgium.org/profiles/ehealth/be-core/application.yaml" hapiproject/hapi:latest . | .

19.title: Publication of specifications
19.content: The publication of specifications is a final step after the the CI build is OK. It follows the process described in the FHIR wiki and requires some preparatory actions: . | Establishing a set of repositories and branches to support the different steps, enable some automation while allowing human control over the entire process | setting up the supporting content for the IG publication steps. | preparing the site(s) where the IG content will be published - CI-build and releases | .

23.title: Specifications
23.content: FHIR specifications define how the capabilities are implemented. There are several types of specifications: . | Data specifications - definitions of the data that is exchanged | Terminology specifications - specifications on terminology - Value Sets, Code Systems, etc. | Data transactions - specifications on how the data is exchanged - triggers, conditions, etc. | . There are other capabilities that systems may support.

24.title: Publication
24.content: The publication process starts with a project initiation phase, which starts with a proposal that describes the content, and is evaluated by the working parties. This proposal, which can be submitted by any institution, is validated by the HL7 Validation Working Group, which designates and/or summons one of the HL7 Belgium FHIR Working Groups for working on the artifacts.

31.title: Documenting Transactions
31.content: Transactions are documented in 2 ways . | Conformance: | Definitions: | .

32.title: Transactions
32.content: Hl7 Belgium specifications specify not only the technical syntax but also the business-level transaction definition. This is done via actors and transactions. Defining the data to be exchanged is one part og the FHIR specifications .

33.title: Translation
33.content: Translations are done in either of 2 ways: . | Inline documentation of technical resources | Professional / external translation | .
